relation: Great for these types of students
It is a very safe campus. Very few incidents happen there.
I think there is one fraternity, but I am not sure.
There are hardly any clubs or activities.

It is great for: -low income students (like myself) -students who prefer small class sizes -students who want to get adjusted to college after high school -students who want to get involved in technical courses
It is the most affordable college in Kentucky. It is very cheap, and to get your Gen Eds out of the way, it is a great deal!
There are a few clubs to do, but there really is not a whole lot to do around campus.
There is no food, or dining halls.

Make sure you know what you want to do after you get your Associate Degree, and know where you want to transfer. And if you are going to the downtown campus, make sure you leave early enough to find parking.
It is a small community college. It is very affordable, and they are very helpful with getting you to transfer! I highly recommend it!

textAfterTable: Bang for the buck The cost is $125 per credit hour, and there is no housing so there is no cost for that as well as food. You can take as many credit hours as you desire, so you yourself can determine how much you pay. There is also great financial aid available that makes it even easier to go to school here. Am enjoying being here I love the friendly feel of Jefferson Community and Technical College campus in Shelbyville. Students come from all walks of life and are willing to talk to people whom they have never met. The professors want to help as much as possible and are willing to work with you inside and outside of class in order to do what it takes to get you through the class with growth and satisfaction. Because of the size of the campus, you see people you know every day, inside and outside of the classroom. Am learning a lot Jefferson Community and Technical College has specified programs between its many campuses, with differing classes at different campuses so that you can find classes that interest you and fit in with your major. The classes go into key ideas and develop into the specifics. You can learn about
